articles.headline: White House Requests More Disaster Aid but Also Seeks Cuts as Deficits Rise
articles.snippet: The White House’s latest disaster relief request pushed the total from this year’s hurricanes and wildfires close to $100 billion, but it came with suggested cuts.
articles.abstract: The White House’s latest disaster relief request pushed the total from this year’s hurricanes and wildfires close to $100 billion, but it came with suggested cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House asked Congress on Friday for $44 billion in additional relief in response to this year’s devastating hurricanes, but facing rising budget deficits and pushing a tax cut that could cost $1.5 trillion, the administration also suggested that lawmakers make spending cuts to offset disaster costs.

articles.headline: Retailers Experiment With a New Philosophy: Smaller Is Better
articles.snippet: Department stores and other retailers struggling to beat back e-commerce are taking cues from online start-ups by experimenting with small showrooms.
articles.abstract: Department stores and other retailers struggling to beat back e-commerce are taking cues from online start-ups by experimenting with small showrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brick-and-mortar retail chains, known for sprawling stores that stock a bit of everything, are trying to lift sagging sales using a different strategy: cozier spaces that sell very little of anything.

articles.headline: Crimes of the Caliphate: Iraqi Shepherd Bears Witness to ISIS Massacre
articles.snippet: As Iraq liberates the last territory from the Islamic State, the country is starting to grapple with the extent of the group’s destruction.
articles.abstract: As Iraq liberates the last territory from the Islamic State, the country is starting to grapple with the extent of the group’s destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAWIJA, Iraq — A shepherd heard the gunshots and the screaming.

articles.headline: A Great Migration From Puerto Rico Is Set to Transform Orlando
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of new arrivals fleeing damage from Hurricane Maria have arrived. Many expect to stay — and they could reshape Florida and its politics.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of new arrivals fleeing damage from Hurricane Maria have arrived. Many expect to stay — and they could reshape Florida and its politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Ten intolerable days after Hurricane Maria trounced Puerto Rico, Sahria Garcia finally got a call from her brother on the island. The call lasted three minutes and the news shook her: Her family had lost everything — jobs, houses, possessions, cars — and had spent days foraging for food, ice and water.

articles.headline: Top Russian Official Tried to Broker ‘Backdoor’ Meeting Between Trump and Putin
articles.snippet: The overture came soon after the Trump campaign was told of Russian “dirt” on Hillary Clinton. As Donald J. Trump neared the Republican nomination, Moscow tried repeatedly to contact his campaign.
articles.abstract: The overture came soon after the Trump campaign was told of Russian “dirt” on Hillary Clinton. As Donald J. Trump neared the Republican nomination, Moscow tried repeatedly to contact his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior Russian official who claimed to be acting at the behest of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia tried in May 2016 to arrange a meeting between Mr. Putin and Donald J. Trump, according to several people familiar with the matter.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: The Kochs Are Inching Closer to Becoming Media Moguls
articles.snippet: As Charles and David Koch back the Meredith Corporation’s effort to buy Time Inc., some see a new way for them to advance their libertarian agenda.
articles.abstract: As Charles and David Koch back the Meredith Corporation’s effort to buy Time Inc., some see a new way for them to advance their libertarian agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Charles G. and David H. Koch seemed poised to control some of the country’s biggest newspapers. Known for using their vast wealth and network of donors to advance their brand of libertarian-infused conservatism, the titans of Koch Industries explored buying the Tribune Company’s eight newspapers, including The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: In Mocking Franken Over Claims of Sexual Misconduct, Trump Joins a Debate He Started
articles.snippet: A typical politician with President Trump’s history would stay far away from discussing someone else’s behavior lest it dredge his own back into the spotlight.
articles.abstract: A typical politician with President Trump’s history would stay far away from discussing someone else’s behavior lest it dredge his own back into the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last fall, Donald J. Trump inadvertently touched off a national conversation about sexual harassment when a recording of him boasting about groping women was made public at the same time a succession of women came forward to assert that groping was something he did more than talk about.

articles.headline: A Hedge Fund Manager Committed Fraud. Would the U.S. Let Him Go?
articles.snippet: Philip Baker admitted that he defrauded his hedge-fund clients. He was sentenced to 20 years in federal prison. Then he devised an escape plan.
articles.abstract: Philip Baker admitted that he defrauded his hedge-fund clients. He was sentenced to 20 years in federal prison. Then he devised an escape plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Forty inmates lined up for the daily mail call at the Fort Dix Federal Correctional Institution, a complex of low-slung brick buildings in the middle of New Jersey.

articles.headline: In China, an Education in Dating
articles.snippet: A new type of coach teaches courtship in a country where the one-child policy left a deficit of women and where flirting remains relatively new.
articles.abstract: A new type of coach teaches courtship in a country where the one-child policy left a deficit of women and where flirting remains relatively new.
articles.lead_paragraph: JINAN, China — Zhang Zhenxiao is 27 years old. He has never been in a relationship. He has never kissed a woman.

articles.headline: For Roy Moore, a Long History of Combat and Controversy
articles.snippet: The current furor surrounding the Senate candidate has played out like a concentrated version of his battle-filled career.
articles.abstract: The current furor surrounding the Senate candidate has played out like a concentrated version of his battle-filled career.
articles.lead_paragraph: GADSDEN, Ala. — It was 1982, and four circuit judges from rural Etowah County, Ala., had filed a state bar complaint against a lawyer named Roy S. Moore, accusing him of running “slanderous” political ads that had portrayed the local legal system as corrupt.
articles.byline: By Jess Bidgood, Richard Fausset and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: When Unpaid Student Loan Bills Mean You Can No Longer Work
articles.snippet: Twenty states suspend people’s professional or driver’s licenses if they fall behind on loan payments, according to records obtained by The New York Times.
articles.abstract: Twenty states suspend people’s professional or driver’s licenses if they fall behind on loan payments, according to records obtained by The New York Times.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fall behind on your student loan payments, lose your job.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Stacy Cowley and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: Why a Firm Believer in Tax Cuts Could Derail the Senate Tax Cut Plan
articles.snippet: Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin, a small-business owner, says the measure would give an unfair advantage to larger corporations.
articles.abstract: Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin, a small-business owner, says the measure would give an unfair advantage to larger corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the eve of the House’s vote to pass a far-reaching $1.5 trillion tax cut, Speaker Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin placed a hasty phone call to his state’s senior senator, Ron Johnson, in hopes of resolving an unlikely conflict in his own back yard.

articles.headline: He Took On the Voting Rights Act and Won. Now He’s Taking On Harvard.
articles.snippet: Edward Blum has orchestrated more than two dozen lawsuits challenging racial preference laws.
articles.abstract: Edward Blum has orchestrated more than two dozen lawsuits challenging racial preference laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH THOMASTON, Me. — A former mayor of Poway, a small city in Southern California, wrote a column in August in his local newspaper with this headline: “A gun to my head.”

articles.headline: Chinese Phone Maker Bets Big With a Premium Price
articles.snippet: Huawei Technologies wants to banish from consumers’ minds the idea that Chinese brands can produce only cheap knockoffs.
articles.abstract: Huawei Technologies wants to banish from consumers’ minds the idea that Chinese brands can produce only cheap knockoffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — The phone takes dazzling photos and sports advanced artificial intelligence. Its display stretches gloriously from edge to edge. And at nearly $1,000, it pushes into eye-watering territory on price.

articles.headline: How ABC Found a Surprise Hit in ‘The Good Doctor’
articles.snippet: The actor Daniel Dae Kim — in his new role as executive producer — was turned down twice by CBS before landing the show at the last-place network.
articles.abstract: The actor Daniel Dae Kim — in his new role as executive producer — was turned down twice by CBS before landing the show at the last-place network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniel Dae Kim was wide awake and scrolling through Twitter at 4 a.m. when he realized “The Good Doctor” was going to be a hit.

articles.headline: Pizza Is Partisan, and Advertisers Are Still Adjusting
articles.snippet: With the country so divided on so many issues, companies are increasingly finding themselves in the middle of controversies. They’re realizing it may be the new normal.
articles.abstract: With the country so divided on so many issues, companies are increasingly finding themselves in the middle of controversies. They’re realizing it may be the new normal.
articles.lead_paragraph: In today’s political climate, even pizza, bourbon and coffee can be partisan issues.

articles.headline: As Silicon Valley Gets ‘Crazy,’ Midwest Beckons Tech Investors
articles.snippet: Funding and start-ups are concentrated on the coasts, especially in California. But there are signs of an entrepreneurial awakening in the heartland, where talent is rich but prices aren’t.
articles.abstract: Funding and start-ups are concentrated on the coasts, especially in California. But there are signs of an entrepreneurial awakening in the heartland, where talent is rich but prices aren’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — They seem an odd couple. J. D. Vance, author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” his best-selling memoir of growing up in the postindustrial Midwest and his journey of escape. And Steve Case, the billionaire co-founder of America Online.

articles.headline: In Race Against Roy Moore, Democratic Candidate Is Mostly on His Own
articles.snippet: Alabama Democrats see a rare chance of victory in the Senate special election. But the party is too diminished to give its candidate, Doug Jones, much help.
articles.abstract: Alabama Democrats see a rare chance of victory in the Senate special election. But the party is too diminished to give its candidate, Doug Jones, much help.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELENA, Ala. — It was unusual enough for Keith Dorsey to open his door in this heavily Republican Birmingham suburb and be greeted by a Democratic canvasser, a sight normally as rare here as a Clemson fan. But these are unusual times.

articles.headline: Behind Mugabe’s Rapid Fall: A Firing, a Feud and a First Lady
articles.snippet: Robert Mugabe’s rule in Zimbabwe went unchallenged for 37 years, but in just a few days, he was largely stripped of power. The chain of events leading to his fall started with firing a vice president.
articles.abstract: Robert Mugabe’s rule in Zimbabwe went unchallenged for 37 years, but in just a few days, he was largely stripped of power. The chain of events leading to his fall started with firing a vice president.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The rapid fall of Zimbabwe’s president, whose legendary guile and ruthlessness helped him outmaneuver countless adversaries over nearly four decades, probably has surprised no one more than Robert Mugabe himself.

articles.headline: In Mexico, Not Dead. Not Alive. Just Gone.
articles.snippet: With the drug war’s “disappeared” numbering in the tens of thousands, some families take up the search for loved ones on their own.
articles.abstract: With the drug war’s “disappeared” numbering in the tens of thousands, some families take up the search for loved ones on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: XALAPA, Mexico — At 5 a.m., the couple stirred to the buzz of a cellphone alarm. They had hardly slept — Carlos Saldaña had been in the hospital the night before, betrayed by his fragile stomach.
